content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Le principe est très intéressant et permet de travailler l'algorithmie basique.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: J'aime bien le principe

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It can be solved

l1, l2, v1, v2, s = map(int, input().split())

v1_m_s = v1 * (1000 / 3600)
v2_m_s = v2 * (1000 / 3600)

v_relative = v1_m_s - v2_m_s

if v_relative <= 0:
    print("Impossible")
else:
    overtaking_time = (l1 + l2) / v_relative
    overtaking_distance = v1_m_s * overtaking_time
    
    if overtaking_distance > s:
        print("Impossible")
    else:
        print(f"{overtaking_distance:.2f}")

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: i cant solve it

This is a nice clash! I did however need to make some assumptions that are not explicitly stated. The situation assumes that you are fully and directly behind the other car, and on separate lanes (so that the distance you have to overtake is l1 + l2).  There are other situations possible, that are not excluded by your statement currently: you are driving behind the other car (and have to move around him); you are driving level with the other car (and hence only need l2).

Also, the phrasing 's m straight sections' gave me the impression that it was a road that has a couple of sections with overtake possibility, and that you somehow had to find out at which section you could take your chance. But, instead, it is a single section of s meter that you are currently on.

Suggestion to rephrase to something like:
"You are driving on the left lane of a two-lane road, your front bumper level with the backside bumper of another car on the right lane. There is s meter (m) left for overtaking. Both vehicles ..."

Input
* Please change "fiveintegers" to "five space-separated integers".

* Line 1 of the stub generator states "read l1:int l2:int v1:int v2:int s:int", but here in Input section the order of the variables is s, l1, l2, v1, v2. Which order is right? Please correct the wrong order.

Output
* Please fix the typo: "vehicule" => "vehicle".

Constraints
* Please delete "(length of the vehicle in m)".

* Please delete "(speed in km/h)".

Thanks.

Input
* Goal section mentions that [[s]] is in km, but Input section says it is in m. Which unit is correct?

* Please change "four" to "five space-separated".

* Please change "L1", "L2", "V1" and "V2" to lowercase for consistency with other sections.

Output
* Please fix the typo: "vehicule" => "vehicle".

* Please format "Impossible" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

Constraints
* Please change 100000 to 1000 because in no cases [[l1]] or [[l2]] exceeds 1000.

* Please delete "(length of the train in m)".

* Please change 500 to 1000 because in some cases [[v2]] is greater than 500.

* Please change "[[v2]" to "[[v2]]".

* Please delete "(speed in km/h)".

Cases
* Each pair of test and validator should be *similar* but *not the same*. Please revise the cases accordingly.

* Pair 3: Please fix the output to show 2 decimal places (i.e. 121.50 instead of 121.5).

Stub generator
* Please replace with the following:

read s:int l1:int l2:int v1:int v2:int
write answer

Thanks.
Just because you can't, doesn't mean its bad

I feel that saying 'Just because you can't, doesn't mean it's bad' is a bit generalized. They are simply expressing their perspective and has the right to reject the task if they find it challenging to solve. 
To be honest, I also found the math on this one a bit tough - it’s meant to be a fun, quick-to-solve task.

https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/39192634c2748c88015ebc900229a39cf63eba4
They could've at least explained what kind of problems they were facing so the person creating the puzzle knows how to improve it
